Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating Models and Observations to Assess Effects of Turbulence on Warm Rain Initiation
Award.AbstractNarration: While the "warm rain" process--in which ice-phase microphysics play little or no role in development of precipitation-size particles--is thought to account for as much as one-third of all tropical precipitation, yet a number of uncertainties remain regarding its exact mechanisms. In particular, the classic theory of condensational growth followed by collision-coalescence accompanying gravitational settling is unable to explain the oft-observed rapid development of rain in clouds confined to temperatures warmer than 0 degC. It has gradually become recognized that turbulence could play a critical role in accelerating this process, but realizable predictions have been difficult to achieve because quantitative research approaches are lacking. Recent advances in theory and computational capacity have enabled more quantitative assessment of turbulence effects on the collision-coalescence rate, and several preliminary parameterizations of turbulent collection have been developed. The goals of this research are to (a) incorporate representation of realistic turbulence-driven collection (i.e. droplet growth) in a large-eddy simulation (LES) model of cloud behavior using a bin microphysical scheme, and subsequently (b) to evaluate resulting predictions using existing in situ observations of real clouds to identify those conditions under which this newly-represented process affects and improves model predictions. Owing to their long lifecycle and a large amount of high-quality observational data available to facilitate real world-model comparisons, marine stratocumulus clouds will be emphasized. A hybrid direct numerical simulation (DNS) approach will be used to develop more accurate parameterization of turbulent collision-coalescence in conditions of low-to-intermediate mean flow dissipation rates, and statistical methods to incorporate such a parameterization into the LES framework will be explored. This approach will be complemented by phenomenological modeling of Reynolds number effects on airflow, and in so doing the LES model will be improved to allow for differing cloud entrainment mixing scenarios. The intellectual merit of this study will center on a more accurate and systematic evolution of the effects of turbulence on realistic stratocumulus conditions and improved assessment of our current ability to represent such effects quantitatively in a predictive mode. Broader Impacts of the effort will include development of findings that should ultimately be applicable to other types of clouds (e.g., more vigorous cumulus) and improved quantitative representation for warm-rain development in more coarse-grained numerical weather prediction and climate models, as well as through enhanced collaboration across the cloud microphysics and computational sciences. This setting will provide a vibrant and multifaceted education and training ground for a mix of undergraduate and graduate students at the two involved institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Precipitation is a key feature of both weather and climate prediction. Our current understanding of what controls the occurrence, amount, intensity and duration of rainfall, on time scales ranging from tomorrow to the end of this century, is known to be lacking. One key gap in our knowledge is the process by which small cloud drops collide with each other, forming larger drops that, after this process is repeated over and over, eventually becomes rain. Our current theory of this collisional process is inadequate to explain observed rainfall. One prominent idea that has recently been the focus of much study is the possibility that turbulence can enhance drop collisions within clouds, thus accelerating rain formation. 


The overall goal of this project was to assess whether our current theories of turbulence effects in clouds could account for the gap between observations and predictions. We have published several studies related to this goal:


1) Witte et al., QJRMS, 2017 (in press): This study quantifies how large the gap is between obervations and predictions of the rate of collisional growth using data collected by aircraft. There has not been a well-quantified assessment of the width of this gap. This paper shows that it can be more than a factor of 10, which is very substantial. We also find that, using a simple model framework, turbulence can potentially close this gap by at most a factor of 2, which is not nearly as much as needed.

2) Witte et al., in prep: The follow-up paper to the previous study uses a more sophisticated model. Our tentative finding is that accounting for turbulence effects does indeed modestly change model simulations, but properties of the model itself, in particular how well drop sizes are resolved, make as much or even more of a difference to the simulation, suggesting that this common tool for studying clouds has important flaws that need to be addressed. The properties of clouds when accounting for turbulence do better match observations, suggesting that it is important to account for these effects. 

3) Rémillard et al., 2017 (in press): This study demonstrates that one reason why models need to be improved for cloud studies is the numerical solution of the equations associated with drop growth artificially enhance this process due to numerical errors. This was done by comparing model results with data collected by radars and aircraft.

4) Witte et al., ACP, 2014: This study describes a novel method by which aircraft data can be used to assess the age of each cloud, which is crucial for understanding aircraft observations of the cloud. As a cloud ages, we expect more and more collisions to have occurred since more time has elapsed. Thus, our prediction of how much collisional growth occurs has to depend on the age of the cloud. Thus, reconciling aircraft observations and predictions of drop collisions requires knowing this age. This paper is the first to address this issue. 

5) Witte et al., GRL, 2017: This study uses the same aircraft data as in items #1, 2 and 3 above to address a separate issue. Satellites (specifically the MODIS instrument) are frequently used to monitor cloud properties around the Earth. Past studies have suggested that MODIS does not accurately measure cloud drop sizes. However, our study is the first to suggest that MODIS actually is accurate, and that the fault in previous studies is due to inadequate aircraft instrumentation. This dramatically improves our confidence in the quality of MODIS cloud data. 

6) Norgren et al., ACP, 2016: This study shows how aircraft observations can be used to deduce entrainment and detrainment from clouds. Entrainment causes clouds to evaporate, and hence limits the amount of precipitation that can fall from a cloud. Both entrainment and detrainment, which is the flow of air out of a cloud, are important processes for all clouds, but evaluating them from aircraft in cumulus clouds has not previously been easy. We propose a new method in this paper that is easy to immplement and provides information about both entrainment and detrainment. One key finding is that detrainment is a very weak process in the clouds we studied, which is potentially inconsistent with previous studies.

Two young scientists, Matthew Norgren and Mikael Witte, were trained as part of this project and have continue to perform atmospheric science research.

Together, these findings help us understand the inner workings of clouds. They have identified new ways to evaluate the processes happening within them, described limitations to the models we use to study them, and generated new and updated knowledge about how they work. A better understanding of clouds is recognized as a key component to improving our ability to predict weather and climate and, therefore, societally important phenomena such as floods, droughts, and climate change.
